headline.main: Study Links Cancer in Young to Fathers' Smoking

keywords.value: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Fathers who smoke have an increased risk of having children with brain cancer and leukemia, suggesting that smoking might have damaged the fathers' sperm, researchers said yesterday. That conclusion is speculative, said Dale P. Sandler of the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences in Research Triangle Park, N.C., who helped write the study. But the study points to the possibility of an effect on sperm. She suggested that "another study with bigger numbers" be undertaken.
